page.title: 18THE RIBBLE MARSHES (CONT)
page.content: The birds depend on the sandbanks, mudflats and saltmarshes for feeding, roosting and breeding. In autumn 50000 -80000 wading birds arrive from their Arctic breeding grounds on migration south to Africa, or to spend the winter here. 30000 waders stay over winter and are joined by 15000-20000 wildfowl, mainly widgeon, pinkfooted geese, teal and pintail. In spring numbers are increased by birds heading north to their breeding grounds. 6000 pairs of black-headed gulls, 200 pairs of redshank and 100 pairs of common tern nest on the marshes, making it a nationally important site. Cattle grazing is very important, balanced to ensure the grass is grazed short enough to enable wigeon and geese to feed on it in winter but not too hard during the summer, so leaving nesting sites for breeding birds.
